AND ASIA. ARRESTS BEING MADE BY THE AUTHORITIES.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I’m gonna get him back Diana. She doesn’t answer. She stares with contempt and rage. As Jack begins to head out of the house...

dialogues.speaker: JACK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I had several million dollars in a duffle bag and had to go and see a bunch of low life Russian mobsters, who would most likely cut my throat, take the money, and kill a kid they think is my son for sport. EXT. - JACK’S HOUSTON HOUSE - NIGHT It's just as beautiful as the inside, surrounded by a private gate. Jack runs through the rain towards his Mercedes with the DUFFLE BAG.

dialogues.speaker: JACK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: It doesn’t get any more fucked up than this. I was dealing with the kind of savages who’d beat their mothers to death for a ham sandwich. So, I didn’t place my odds as very good for seeing the sun come up.  Jack starts his car and begins pulling out of the driveway as the gate opens up.

dialogues.speaker: JACK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And why? Because of what I had a hand in creating. No, I didn’t cure AIDS or cancer. And I didn’t figure out a way to stop war or end world hunger. But I did end up making a lot more money than if I'd done any of those great and lasting things that would change the world for the better. INT. — JACK'S MERCEDES - NIGHT Jack tries to light a cigarette. His hands shake so badly, he can hardly do it.

dialogues.speaker: JACK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I had a hand in creating the greatest invention of our time. I inadvertently changed the world. My name is Jack Harris, and I figured out a better way for guys to jerk off. Montage of shots through history. Pornographic sex, masturbation...dating back to caves through the Kama Sutra.

dialogues.speaker: JACK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Men have been jerking off since the beginning of time. I mean, it’s no fucking secret. 1950's. A young boy masturbating to beauties on the Milton Berle show, Betty Page, etc. His mother walks in and begins screaming at him.

dialogues.speaker: JACK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Why is this mother yelling at her kid? She should know better. Men are always thinking about sex. About every ten seconds some sick, perverted, degenerate thought goes through a man’s mind. Through the 60’s, 70’s and 80’s. Different porn styles, women with big hairy bush, John Holmes style guys, mullet beefcakes posing with porno babes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From the very moment a man figures out his hand can reach his dick, he’s figuring out a new way to pull on it. A skateboard kid locks his door, pops in a VHS cassette. Then through the 90’s, hardcore porn on A DVD. Stay on the TV, a US Senator now gives a speech on how he’s going to clean up the world. Later, in his hotel room, he jerks it furiously while wearing women’s underwear.

dialogues.speaker: JACK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: This should come as no big fucking surprise. Every guy, gay or straight, prince or pauper, kings, presidents, heads of state, every last one of them is sneaking off somewhere and whacking it. A GOTH kid ties a rope around his neck, jacking off. He finishes, his feet can’t quite make it back to the chair. He’s choking, and it’s clear he’s not going to make it.

dialogues.speaker: JACK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Look at this poor fucker. His inventiveness will be the thing that does him in. It’s been a preoccupation of men since God knows when. Still don’t believe me? Well, look at this. A space shuttle is launched.

dialogues.speaker: JACK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: This is the space shuttle. It costs four hundred and fifty million dollars every time it’s launched by Uncle Sam and your tax dollars. Guess what’s on it? In space, we see a satellite released into orbit.

dialogues.speaker: JACK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: A billion dollar satellite. And why do you think they’re launching that thing? It’s all part of the Internet. But if you think that thing has anything to do with helping your kids learn, daddy reading stats on Tiger Woods, or Mommy and Grandma learning how to bake the perfect chocolate cake, then you’re out of your fucking mind. Just follow the money. The porn industry takes in fifty seven billion dollars a year worldwide. With no one ever admitting that they watch... We see a farmhouse right out of an Andrew Wyeth painting A farmer, done from plowing his field, heads merrily up the stairs into his house.

dialogues.speaker: JACK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: This is going on every second of every day all over the world. Inside the house, his wife, right out of a Norman Rockwell painting, is baking an apple pie. Two angelic kids beam when the pie is placed on the table to cool off.

dialogues.speaker: JACK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Millions and millions and millions of horny, frustrated guys, escaping into porn dream land. In the other room, the farmer has a laptop computer running wireless Internet. We PAN to the modem/port, which creates a laser beam...we follow it up out of the house into space where the laser bounces off the satellite and comes shooting back down to earth.

dialogues.speaker: JACK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: It’s a land of women, gorgeous women, who don’t know the meaning of the word “no”. It shoots off another giant satellite dish and fires back out hundreds of miles into a cable compound which shoots the beam, from miles away, back into the modem/port...AND THEN... The farmer, sitting in front of his computer, undoes his overalls. A porn scene plays on his laptop...He smiles wide-eyed...

dialogues.speaker: JACK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Pure Americana...

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. — JACK'S MERCEDES - NIGHT Back to the present. Jack tries to light another cigarette, his hand is now shaking even worse. He drops the lighter. Jack yanks the wheel hard.  EXT. -— ROAD SIDE - NIGHT The car screeches over to the side of the road. Jack puts the car in park as the rain pours down. He checks the time on the clock... 11:59...He takes a deep breath...the clock on the dash turns to midnight.

dialogues.speaker: JACK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And no matter how many times I roll this over in my head, I keep asking myself the same question; How the fuck did I let things go this far?

dialogues.speaker: FADE IN
dialogues.text: EXT. — CHURCH LAWN - DAY

dialogues.speaker: IMPOSE LEGEND
dialogues.text: A church picnic. Crowds. Everything is right in white America. Kids, parents, balloons. An endless spread of food on picnic tables. The camera cranes down over the scene and finds a younger Jack. He’s holding two plates of fried chicken, mashed potatoes, corn. He’s dressed a lot less stylishly than the older version of him.

dialogues.speaker: JACK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Back then things seemed so simple. He heads over to a younger Diana. She turns, beaming. They are very much in love. They kiss and sit at the end of a picnic table, away from the crowds. Jack takes a bite of chicken.

dialogues.speaker: JACK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I can always tell your fried chicken from someone else’s. They both eat.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: Is that right?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Yeah. What’s your secret?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A chef doesn’t divulge her secrets.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: It's not like I’m a stranger.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: You marry me, I’1l tell you. He smiles for a minute, puts down his food, gets up from sitting and kneels in front of her. He takes her hand.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Diana, will you marry me? She smiles from somewhere deep inside.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: Pepper.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: Pepper.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Pepper? That’s it?

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: Sorry you signed your life away?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: God no! He kisses her, gently. They fall into each others arms.

dialogues.speaker: JACK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I was one of those guys living in a Norman Rockwell painting. And looking back, I had no idea how happy I really Was...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We think we are in heaven. The clouds part to reveal Los Angeles.  10 11

dialogues.speaker: JACK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Now across the gulf of space, on another planet called Los Angeles, California, my fate was already being sealed...

dialogues.speaker: IMPOSE LEGEND
dialogues.text: EXT. — VAN NUY’S APARTMENT COMPLEX - NIGHT It’s a run-down shit hole. We hear gunshots firing in the distance. INT. - VAN NUY’S APARTMENT, LIVING ROOM - NIGHT BUCK COLBY sleeps in a beat up recliner. He’s in his twenties and from the South. If it’s conceivable, he’s smarter than his roommate... INT. - VAN NUY’S APARTMENT, BEDROOM - NIGHT WAYNE BEER is coked to the gills and is playing with his computer. He is clearly frustrated. He gets up and heads for the living room. INT. - VAN NUY’S APARTMENT, LIVING ROOM - NIGHT Wayne enters. He looks at Buck, as he sleeps.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: How can you sleep in a chair? Buck waking up.

dialogues.speaker: BUCK
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: How can you sleep in a fucking chair?

dialogues.speaker: BUCK
dialogues.text: You mean, how can I sleep with all this noise, don’t you?

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: You know there’s nothing to jerk to on the fucking Internet. 10 11

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So watch a DVD you degenerate.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: I’m a degenerate? You bought all these DVD's and I’m a degenerate?

dialogues.speaker: BUCK
dialogues.text: You watched them all a hundred times. That’s why you need new shit. Yeah, you're a fucking degenerate.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: Fuck you. Don’t get all high and mighty with me.

dialogues.speaker: BUCK
dialogues.text: Fuck me? Stop doing all this coke and smoking all these fucking cigarettes! I got to go to work in the morning and I can’t sleep choking on all this smoke.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: You smoke, you fucking asshole!

dialogues.speaker: BUCK
dialogues.text: Not when I’m sleeping! And clean this place up. It’s like living in a toxic waste dump!

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: Wow. Lucky me. I get to live with Martha fucking Stewart.

dialogues.speaker: BUCK
dialogues.text: If I was Martha fucking Stewart you would be jerking off in front of me all fucking day, you fucking loser! Wayne raises his fist.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: Don’t call me a loser.

dialogues.speaker: BUCK
dialogues.text: Don’t square off with me! I’1l kick your ass around this apartment for drill. Wayne keeps waving his fist.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: Take it back!  12 13

dialogues.speaker: BUCK
dialogues.text: No. I’m not taking anything back, loser. Wayne dives on Buck. The two of them crash to the floor and begin swinging at each other. Real fists are being thrown. As they hold each other in duel choke holds, both of them turning red, we freeze frame.

dialogues.speaker: JACK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: What these two idiots don’t know, is that they’re less than a year away from being worth millions and millions of dollars, and turning the Internet into what it is today. Ain’t America great? (Beat) Maybe I should go back even further.

dialogues.speaker: IMPOSE LEGEND
dialogues.text: CORKSCREW PAN of a 757 landing. The wheels touch down.

dialogues.speaker: JACK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Buck had gotten to LA only two months before. He had this crazy notion about moving out to Los Angeles and getting an honest job. He had problems with the honest job part before. INT. —- WAYNE’S CHEVY NOVA - DAY 13 Wayne and Buck are leaving the airport, sitting in traffic. The car is littered with fast food boxes and soda cans.

dialogues.speaker: BUCK
dialogues.text: How do you live with this kind of traffic everyday?

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: I don’t go out all that much.

dialogues.speaker: BUCK
dialogues.text: Don’t you have a job?

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: I've been collecting disability, but it runs out in a few months.  14 10.

dialogues.speaker: BUCK
dialogues.text: Disability for what?

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: I fell. Told the fuckers I was going to sue.

dialogues.speaker: BUCK
dialogues.text: Then what are you gonna do?

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: Fuck if I know. But I feel like I’m on the verge of something.

dialogues.speaker: BUCK
dialogues.text: Yeah, me too, dude. No, I’m serious. I feel like I’m on the verge of something. I got all these ideas. Dude, these ideas, they just come rushing at me! Idea, after idea, after idea! It’s like a waterfall you know!

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: A cascade...

dialogues.speaker: BUCK
dialogues.text: Yeah man, a cascade!

dialogues.speaker: JACK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Like I said, they’re morons, right? Well that’s not entirely true...

dialogues.speaker: IMPOSE LEGEND
dialogues.text: INT. —- NASA HALLWAY - DAY 14 TWO SECURITY GUARDS move quickly down a hallway with purpose.

dialogues.speaker: JACK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Believe it or not, Buck Colby was some kind of big shot rocket scientist at NASA at the age of 22. He apparently has an IQ of 187, although you’d never know it talking to the guy... The security guards turn the corner and enter another room.  15 16 17 11. INT. - OUTER CHAMBER OF “NO-GRAVITY ROOM” - DAY 15 The security guards move quickly across the room and over to a window that looks inside a wind tunnel. Buck is coked out of his mind, complete with a bloody nose, that flows all over his shirt. He is floating in thin air in 200 mph headwinds. The guards stare incredulously.

dialogues.speaker: JACK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Buck’s favorite thing in the world to do, was spending weekends at NASA, getting coked to the gills and floating in space. The security guards throw a switch. Buck crashes to the floor instantly.

dialogues.speaker: JACK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Needless to say, he got fired. INT. —- VETERINARY CLINIC, EXAMINATION ROOM - DAY 16 ANGLE ON a WOMAN holding a small dog who is happily barking and wagging his tail.

dialogues.speaker: JACK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: From what I understand, Wayne was a terrific Veterinarian. He even taught some classes.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: Are you sure you’re going to have to operate? He looks perfectly fine.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: Hey lady, who’s the doctor here, you or me?

dialogues.speaker: JACK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The only problem was that he started performing unnecessary surgeries ensure a steady supply of canine barbiturates. INT. - VETERINARY CLINIC, WAYNE’S OFFICE - DAY 17 Wayne sits at his desk. He holds a pill bottle up to his lips, tilting the contents back into his mouth.  18 12. His door opens. Wayne freezes, bottle at his lips. One of the other vets stares back at him.

dialogues.speaker: JACK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: That pretty much ended Wayne’s career as a veterinarian.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack and Diana are in a different house. Smaller, quaint, not the palace we saw them in earlier. Diana hangs up the phone. She’s just gotten bad news. Jack sits at the kitchen table. He’s doing their bills, credit card payments stacked high.

dialogues.speaker: JACK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Meanwhile, I find out that a friend of mine who owned a night club out in LA had a heart attack. Diana is explaining the same information.

dialogues.speaker: JACK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Is he gonna be alright?

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: Yeah, but he can’t work for a while. Susan called and wanted to know if you'd go out to LA for a few weeks and help straighten out his business. I talked to their lawyer out there, a guy named Jerry Haggerty. He says the place could be a gold mine, but if you don’t get out there and help now, Susan says they are going to lose everything.

dialogues.speaker: JACK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The last thing I wanted to do was leave my family. I was happy in Houston. I was broke, but at least I was happy...

dialogues.speaker: JACK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Honey, I don’t want to run a night club. The place is probably a mess. It’1l take a lot more than a couple of weeks to straighten it out.

dialogues.speaker: DIANA
dialogues.text: Jack, you're good at fixing messes. That’s what you do.  19 20 21 13.

dialogues.speaker: JACK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: She was right. If I had one talent, it was fixing shit,shit that nobody thought could be fixed.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: EXT. -— CHICAGO - DAY 19 Establishing shot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Cadillac is parked outside an Irish Bar.

dialogues.speaker: JACK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: When I was eighteen I was working for one of my Dad's buddies who owned a construction company in Chicago. There was a lot of money floating around, but even with as much money as there was, there were always problems.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see an eighteen year old Jack sitting in the car with a silver haired wise guy named JOHNNY LA LA, who seems surprisingly calm.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Now let’s go knee cap this Irish fuck and get something to eat.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Knee cap?

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Yeah, knee cap. You take a bat, bing bang, he’s crippled, and he wises up real quick. Jack gulps hard.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Why exactly are we doing this?  14. Johnny gives him an odd look.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: What do you need, a fucking road map, kid? This guy owes me thirty six grand! Let’s hurry up and do this.

dialogues.speaker: JACK, (STALLING)
dialogues.text: Do you know why he can’t pay, help me understand? I don’t understand.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: How the fuck should I know? He owes, end of story! What the fuck kid?

dialogues.speaker: JACK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Most people would have just done what they were told. But it just didn’t sit well with me.

dialogues.speaker: JACK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I mean what if you just talked to the guy and found out what happened. Something had to happen or this guy would be able to pay, right? If you just talked to the guy......

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Kid, I’m done talking to this prick!

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Ok, ok, I’m sorry, I just thought maybe there was a way where you can get your money, which is what you want, right. Johnny is quiet for a moment, confused. Then a smile comes to his face.

dialogues.speaker: JACK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Kid, you think too much. (To Driver) This fuckin’ kid. (Back to Jack) Alright. Hurry up before I change my mind.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: What?  15.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: You got two minutes kid to go in there and get me my money, after that, somebody's knee caps are gettin’ broke.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Me? Hold on...

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: You take your best shot. This is how you learn. Jack gets out of the car and heads for the bar.

dialogues.speaker: JACK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I knew I had two minutes to get Johnny what he wanted and stop something bad from happening. I knew something else too, I did not want to be a part of what Johnny was capable of.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack sits opposite MORGAN, who taps his leg incessantly, a nervous wreck.

dialogues.speaker: MORGAN
dialogues.text: Look kid, I got problems too. I got kids, I got a wife in the hospital, which isn’t that bad considering she cheats on me every fucking week, my house is about to be foreclosed, my oldest son is a smack addict, the last two projects I built got me so jammed up I had to go to Johnny, which is the last fuckin thing I ever wanted to do, now I am sittin here waiting to go to the fucking hospital myself because of what? Because I owe? I mean I didn’t steal... Jack glances at his watch.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Stop. Let's focus on why we're here. You obviously borrowed this money and you had to have a plan on how you were going to pay it back. Tell me what went wrong and maybe I can figure a way out of this.  23 16.

dialogues.speaker: MORGAN
dialogues.text: If I had the fucking building permit I could get to work and I'd be able pay him by the end of the day...

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: And how’s that?

dialogues.speaker: MORGAN
dialogues.text: I can borrow the money in ten seconds if I have the permit. I don’t have the permit.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: A building permit?

dialogues.speaker: MORGAN
dialogues.text: Yes, a building permit.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Stay here. Don’t move. Jack glances at his watch and gets up. EXT. -— IRISH BAR - DAY 23 Jack leaves the bar. Johnny closes the trunk, a Louisville slugger in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: Batter up!

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Hold on Johnny. You have friends downtown right?

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: I got friends all over the place.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: He says he needs a building permit, then he can pay you by the end of the day.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: He wants me to do what? What do I look like, a permiteer?!?

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Johnny, do you want the money, or do you want to break his legs?  24 25 26 17.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY
dialogues.text: (contemplating) I'm in a quandary... Johnny smiles and pats Jack on the side of the face.

dialogues.speaker: JOHNNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You're alright kid. Maybe you should come by the house sometime, maybe talk to my wife. RESUME INT. - JACK’S HOUSTON HOUSE, KITCHEN - DAY 24 Jack sits opposite Diana.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Alright. I guess I’ll go to L.A. The money wouldn’t hurt.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT. - BUCK’S OFFICE - DAY 25

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cubicle after cubicle. It’s worse than any jail cell. Buck sits in his. It’s all over his face. He’s tortured. He opens and closes a ZIPPO lighter over and over, staring out at his co workers.

dialogues.speaker: JACK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Now about the same time, Buck got some shit job in Los Angeles. The nine to five scene just wasn’t for him... Buck’s SUPERVISOR stares at him, not digging his work ethic. INT. —- VAN NUY’S APARTMENT, LIVING ROOM - NIGHT 26 Buck is on the recliner, under a blanket, and Wayne is sitting on the couch, playing with his computer.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: What good is this stupid Internet for? I mean, if you could see some hot porn, maybe it would be worthwhile. I mean, am I right? Buck is trying to watch Jay Leno.  18.

dialogues.speaker: BUCK
dialogues.text: Yeah, I guess...

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: No. I mean, I’m right, right? Look at this shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see lame low resolution pictures of horny housewives and trailer park babes.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This is all lame shit. There’s no variety. There’s nothing new. What if this shit were good? Right? Are you with me?

dialogues.speaker: BUCK
dialogues.text: No. What’s your point?

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: If we took pictures from magazines and put them up there, I bet we could make some money, right?

dialogues.speaker: BUCK
dialogues.text: Oh, sure. You’1l get rich.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: Really? Am I right?

dialogues.speaker: BUCK
dialogues.text: No. Maybe you'd get chump change from a few degenerates, but you’d be lucky to get that. Wayne rubs his face.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: Yeah, I know. And what would you do? Write a check? There’s like a stumbling block in my master plan.

dialogues.speaker: BUCK
dialogues.text: How about credit cards? Wayne jumps to his feet.  27 28 19.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: Credit cards! That’s it, bro! Credit cards! You're like a fucking genius!

dialogues.speaker: BUCK
dialogues.text: Sit down. Who'd give you their credit card number?

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: Fuck, I’m doing this. You laugh, but watch what happens.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: - VAN NUY’S APARTMENT, LIVING ROOM - DAY 27 The next afternoon. The site is up. It’s called “Porno Junkies”. Their logo is up all the time as a screensaver. Buck stares at it, eating a slice of pizza.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: I hooked up a buzzer. Every time we make a sale, the buzzer will go off. See? You ain’t the only one with ideas.

dialogues.speaker: BUCK
dialogues.text: What’d you charge for this?

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: Ten bucks.

dialogues.speaker: BUCK
dialogues.text: No, no. Do nine ninety nine a month, like a magazine.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: Yeah, like a fucking magazine. Right?

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: - VAN NUY’S APARTMENT, BEDROOM - NIGHT 28 A few nights later.

dialogues.speaker: JACK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: So, three or four days go by without a single buzzer. My guess is they almost forgot they even bothered to do this. And then...  29 30 20. We hear a buzzer. Wayne sits up, rubbing his eyes. He looks at the clock. It’s four fifteen in the morning. He stumbles out of bed and heads over to the computer. Buck walks into the bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: BUCK
dialogues.text: Did I hear right?

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: Yeah. We just made nine ninety nine. A GRAPH APPEARS AT THE BOTTOM OF THE SCREEN. It clearly reads nine ninety nine. This graph will remain through the next bunch of scenes, ticking off the money as it comes in.

dialogues.speaker: BUCK
dialogues.text: At four fifteen in the morning? This guy’s got to be a pervert just like you.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: You don’t know that. It might be some guy’s morning jerk back on the east coast, or in Europe, or some fucking place where it’s night. It’s the world wide web dumbass. This guy could be anywhere. INT. - VAN NUY’S APARTMENT, KITCHEN - MORNING 29 Buck is making coffee, getting ready for work. He hears the buzzer. Followed closely by another buzzer. And then, the buzzing just seems to keep on going.

dialogues.speaker: BUCK

dialogues.speaker: BUCK
dialogues.text: How much are we up to? INT. —- VAN NUY’S APARTMENT, LIVING ROOM - DAY 31

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE

dialogues.text: I've got this set up so that we can tell what pics we’re selling based on the sound. The buzzer is the trailer trash stuff. The chime is over forty. The whistle is all the big titty stuff. And the bell is the ass fucking housewives.

JACK'S FATHER (CONT’D) Pay attention. Young Jack nods.  34 35 23. JACK'S FATHER (CONT’D) You're the oldest. You're gonna have to go to work. Even if I make it through this, I'm gonna be out of commission for a while. You gotta watch the business. Things are tough right now.

dialogues.text: Yeah Dad.

dialogues.speaker: JACK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: So I went to work. My life has always been a contradiction. Prep school to working for a wise guy. Church picnics to night clubs. But somehow it worked out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jack sits waiting for his flight to Los Angeles, deep in thought. The announcer calls for Jack’s flight. He grabs his carry on and gets up. INT. - VAN NUY’S APARTMENT, LIVING ROOM - NIGHT 35 Buck comes out of his bedroom. He can’t sleep. It’s a cacophony of bells, buzzers, whistles and chimes. The sound that rings with most frequency is the bell.  36 24. The counter at the bottom of the screen is now over five thousand dollars.

dialogues.speaker: BUCK
dialogues.text: Wayne! Wayne emerges from his bedroom.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: (re: bell) Seems like ass fucking housewives is a big hit. Buck pulls the plug.

dialogues.speaker: WAYNE
dialogues.text: Dude. We’re over the seven thousand dollar mark.

dialogues.text: One six foot Russian beauty after another dances naked on stage amongst cat calls, smoke, and blasting music. Buck and Wayne enter the club and are stopped by an enormous Russian bouncer.

dialogues.speaker: JACK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Now what these two idiots didn’t know is that Nikita Sokoloff, the head of the entire west coast Russian mob, owned the joint. And they were about to get more than they bargained for...

dialogues.speaker: SMASH CUT TO
dialogues.text: 39 26. INT. — NIKITA SOKOLOFF’S OFFICE - NIGHT 39 It's a large plush office loaded with pictures of naked women. The Russian bouncers use Buck and Wayne’s heads to open the door. They both yelp as they are tossed to the carpet. NIKITA SOKOLOFF stands in front of them. He has a thick Russian accent and is very hard to understand. Especially when he’s angry, which he seems to be right now.

dialogues.speaker: NIKITA
dialogues.text: Who the fuck, are you to come, into my place, and talk this kind of shit?!? Buck and Wayne, both on all fours, eyeball each other.

Wayne turns to the nearly naked Ukrainian dancer sitting at his side.

INT. —- VAN NUY’S APARTMENT, LIVING ROOM - DAY 42 Printouts overflowing into a garbage can, totally disorganized business mayhem. There is more paperwork coming in than the men know what to do with or are capable of handling. SINGLE SHOT: MAILMAN drops an entire bag of mail at the door that would take a month to sort. Buck is on the phone, Wayne pacing in the background.

dialogues.speaker: JACK, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: So now they have to purchase a bigger server to handle all of the business. The mail is piling up and they haven't even thought of opening it. These two fuckers have no idea what they've started. Within days, they're working around the clock. Buck hangs up the phone.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: I love you, baby.

dialogues.text: Because Jack, it could be a herd.

dialogues.text: 59 Jack stare Off Jack's 36.

INT. —- HARD ROCK HOTEL, CASINO - DAY 59 Jack is greeted by RICHARD WILK a casino executive at the door, Jack and Richard move across the crowded floor. Jack nods,

Knowing Haggerty, he already had that part figured out. He was already being investigated by the feds, and stunk of desperation. If this was real, and I was going to get involved, he could not be a part of this, no matter what.

dialogues.text: 60 61 62 37. INT. —- HARD ROCK HOTEL, SUITE - DAY 60 We're back in the hotel suite. Buck and Wayne are partying, having a great time with the out call hookers. Haggerty is off to the side, supplying the coke. INT. —- HARD ROCK HOTEL, HALLWAY - DAY 61

dialogues.text: From what Haggerty told me I knew there was a lot of money in this deal. And that was good. The money was in porn. And that was bad. Why I even knocked on that door is beyond me. Jack knocks on the door to the suite. He hears rustling on the other side.

dialogues.speaker: JACK
dialogues.text: Jack Harris. The door opens. Buck checks him out and pulls him inside. INT. —- HARD ROCK HOTEL, SUITE - DAY 62 The place is enormous. It looks like a bomb hit it, filled with room service carts, and piles of cigarette butts that spill out everywhere and onto the floor. It’s real “Fear and Loathing in Las Vegas” type stuff. Wayne comes up behind Jack and tosses him into the wall, putting a gun to his head. He pulls back the hammer. Buck jumps in the way.

dialogues.text: Don’t mind him, he’s been up for eleven straight days. Jack turns and gets his first good look at Wayne. He is dressed only in a robe, which periodically opens up, his dick hanging out. This makes Jack visibly uncomfortable.

dialogues.text: I'll eat the food first. If it’s good, I‘1ll hand it over to you.
